Content

- 1. Keyed Collections
- 2. Map - Keyed Collections

1. Iterators and generators

- Iterators vaÌ€ generators Ä‘Æ°Æ¡Ì£c xÃ¢y dÆ°Ì£ng bÃªn trong Core-Language, cung cÃ¢Ìp cÆ¡ chÃªÌ Ä‘ÃªÌ‰ tuÌ€y biÃªÌn voÌ€ng lÄƒÌ£p nhÆ° for...of
- Iterator laÌ€ mÃ´Ì£t object maÌ€ bÃªn trong noÌ Ä‘Æ°Æ¡Ì£c xÃ¢y dÆ°Ì£ng iterator protocol, coÌ phÆ°Æ¡ng thÆ°Ìc next, iterator goÌ£i phÆ°Æ¡ng thÆ°Ìc next traÌ‰ vÃªÌ€ value: The next value in the iteration vaÌ€ done : true/ false
- TaÌ£o ra mÃ´Ì£t Object Iterator bÄƒÌ€ng caÌch sÆ°Ì‰ duÌ£ng phÆ°Æ¡ng thÆ°Ìc [Symbol.iterator]()

2. What is Iterable ?

- Iterable : An Object is iterable if that Object implement the @@iterator method. This means (or one of the objects up its prototype chain) must have a property with a Symbol.iterator key.
- String, Array, TypedArray, Map and Set are all built-in iterables, because their prototype objects all have a Symbol.iterator method.

3. What is Iterator?

An Iterator is any Object which implements the Iterator protocol by having a next() method that returns an object with two properties:
- value: The next value in the iteration sequence.
- done: This is true if the last value in the sequence has already been consumed. If value is present alongside done, it is the iterator's return value.
// Example iterator 
const array = [1,2,3,4,5,6]; // Array is an object built-in iterables
const iterator = array[Symbol.iterator]() // Create iterator object by using method [Symbol.iterator]
console.log( iterator ) ; // Array IteratorÂ {}
console.log( iterator.next() ) ; // {value: 1, done: false}
console.log( iterator.next() ) ; // {value: 2, done: false}
console.log( iterator.next() ) ; // {value: 3, done: false}
console.log( iterator.next() ) ; // {value: 4, done: false}
console.log( iterator.next() ) ; // {value: 5, done: false}
console.log( iterator.next() ) ; // {value: 6, done: false}
console.log( iterator.next() ) ; // {value: undefined, done: true}

4. What is Generator ?

The Generator object is returned by a Generator function and it conforms to both the iterable protocol and the iterator protocol. 
//1 - Example Create Generator
function * createGenerator() {
  yield 1;
  yield 2;
  yield 3;
  return "finished";
}

const generator = createGenerator();
console.log( generator.next() ); // {value: 1, done: false}
console.log( generator.next() ); // {value: 2, done: false}
console.log( generator.next() ); // {value: 3, done: false}
console.log( generator.next() ); // {value: "finished", done: true}
console.log( generator.next() ); // {value: undefined, done: true}
console.log( generator.next() ); // {value: undefined, done: true}

//2 - Example Create Generator 
function * createGenerator(arr) {
    let start = 0 ;
    while(start < arr.length){
        yield arr[start];
        start++
    }
}

const generator = createGenerator([1,2,3])
console.log( generator.next() ); // {value: 1, done: false}
console.log( generator.next() ); // {value: 2, done: false}
console.log( generator.next() ); // {value: 3, done: false}
console.log( generator.next() ); // {value: undefined, done: true}
console.log( generator.next() ); // {value: undefined, done: true}
console.log( generator.next() ); // {value: undefined, done: true}

5. Generator Object ?

- Generator Object was created by Generator Function.
Generator Object inherit Prototype methods
  1. Generator.prototype.next()
  2. Generator.prototype.return()
  3. Generator.prototype.throw()

6. Make Range Iterator

//1 - Example range iterator by Closures
function makeRangeIterator(start = 0, end = Infinity, step = 1) {
  let nextIndex = start;
  let iterationCount = 0;

  const rangeIterator = {
    next() {
      let result;
      if (nextIndex <= end) {
        result = { value: nextIndex, done: false };
        nextIndex += step;
        iterationCount++;
        return result;
      }
      return { value: undefined , done: true };
    }
  };
  return rangeIterator;
}

const it = makeRangeIterator(1, 6, 1);

console.log(it.next()); // {value: 1, done: false}
console.log(it.next()); // {value: 2, done: false}
console.log(it.next()); // {value: 3, done: false}
console.log(it.next()); // {value: 4, done: false}
console.log(it.next()); // {value: 5, done: false}
console.log(it.next()); // {value: 6, done: false}
console.log(it.next()); // {value: undefined, done: true}
console.log(it.next()); // {value: undefined, done: true}
console.log(it.next()); // {value: undefined, done: true}
console.log(it.next()); // {value: undefined, done: true}

//2 - Make Range Iterator by function Generator
function* makeRangeIterator(start = 0, end = Infinity, step = 1) {
  let iterationCount = 0;
  for (let i = start; i < end; i += step) {
    iterationCount++;
    yield i;
  }
  return iterationCount;
}

const itGenerator = makeRangeIterator(1, 6, 1);

console.log(itGenerator.next()); // {value: 1, done: false}
console.log(itGenerator.next()); // {value: 2, done: false}
console.log(itGenerator.next()); // {value: 3, done: false}
console.log(itGenerator.next()); // {value: 4, done: false}
console.log(itGenerator.next()); // {value: 5, done: false}
console.log(itGenerator.next()); // {value: 6, done: false}
console.log(itGenerator.next()); // {value: undefined, done: true}
console.log(itGenerator.next()); // {value: undefined, done: true}
console.log(itGenerator.next()); // {value: undefined, done: true}
console.log(itGenerator.next()); // {value: undefined, done: true}
